themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The text explicitly identifies itself as a decree and outlines the formal decisions made by the association of landowners regarding honors and building maintenance.
themes.quote: τ δ γμα το το δισσ ν πογραφ ν στω κ ριον κα β βαιον

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription is dedicated to honoring Apollonius for his virtue, benevolence, and financial contributions to the community, granting him specific privileges like crowning and a shield-monument.
themes.quote: τιμ σαι α τ ν χωρ ς ν προ χει τιμ ν

themes.label: Building Commemoration
themes.rationale: A significant portion of the text commemorates the reconstruction of the association's house and its facilities after a flood, detailing the plastering and paving work.
themes.quote: τ ν ο κον νωικοδ μησε κα τ χρηστ ρια π ντα

themes.label: Accounts and Financial Records
themes.rationale: The text records specific financial transactions, including a 500-drachma contribution for building expenses and a 3000-drachma fine for non-compliance with the decree.
themes.quote: ργυρ ου δραχμ ς πεντακοσ ας

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The inscription begins with a standard invocation to Good Fortune, which is a common religious formula in official and dedicatory texts.

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The decree specifies that the text should be engraved on a stone stele and placed on one of the doorposts of the building.
themes.quote: νχαρ ξαντα ε ς στ λην

persons.name: Theon
persons.role: Former High Priest and father of Apollonius

persons.name: Caesar
persons.role: Roman Emperor Augustus, used for dating

rationale: This inscription is a comprehensive decree from an association of landowners in Psenemphaia, Egypt, dated to 5 BC (Year 25 of Caesar). It honors Apollonius, son of Theon, for his exceptional generosity in rebuilding the association's meeting house and its facilities at his own expense after they were destroyed by a flood. The decree outlines specific honors, such as the right to wear a crown and the placement of a shield-monument, and establishes a heavy fine of 3000 drachmas for anyone attempting to rescind these honors. The text concludes with instructions for the decree to be recorded in the association's books and engraved on a stele.
